entry.title: Announcing: Iron Blogger SF
entry.content:
The first week of the new year: time to make resolutions about the sort of person you want to be, and the sorts of behaviors you want to have. Go to the gym, blog more, that sort of thing.

Of course, these promises don’t usually pan out on the strength of the resolution alone; you need a bit of a carrot and/or a stick to make you stick to it.

So it’s in that spirit that I introduce the San Francisco chapter of Iron Blogger. Inspired by Mako’s Iron Blogger in Boston, and joining my friends Iron-Blogging in Berlin, I decided it was time to put some skin (or at least a few dollars) into the blogging game.

In case you don’t know the rules of Iron Blogger: every participant must post something to her blog every week. If she fails, she owes the organizer $5. (That’s the stick.) Once enough money has been collected, everybody goes out and gets beer with it. (That’s the carrot.) I’ve gotten a group of friends together to start, and if you’re in San Francisco and interested in participating, let me know.

I’m looking forward to it!
entry.summary: The first week of the new year: time to make resolutions about the sort of person you want to be, and the sorts of behaviors you want to have. Go to the gym, blog more, that sort of thing.

entry.title: Dice mosaics
entry.content:
I put together some mosaics of common images using dice faces as tiles. So far they only exist in computerized form, but the hope is to buy some dice wholesale and actually arrange some of these on a board. I’m still experimenting with what kinds of source images make for good output, but for now I’ve stuck to simple black-and-white symbols and line drawings. I’d like to start using more grayscale and complex shapes, but the challenge is keeping the image clear at a resolution low enough that the dice are still discernible and reasonable to arrange. (Some of these contain thousands of dice, which is a bit impractical.)

[![](https://parkerhiggins.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/copyleft-scaled-150x150.png)](https://parkerhiggins.net/2011/01/dice-mosaics/copyleft-scaled/)
[![](https://parkerhiggins.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/copyright-scaled-150x150.png)](https://parkerhiggins.net/2011/01/dice-mosaics/copyright-scaled/)
[![](https://parkerhiggins.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/dice-scaled-150x150.png)](https://parkerhiggins.net/2011/01/dice-mosaics/dice-scaled/)
[![](https://parkerhiggins.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/interrobang-scaled-150x150.png)](https://parkerhiggins.net/2011/01/dice-mosaics/interrobang-scaled/)
[![](https://parkerhiggins.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/mickey-scaled-150x150.png)](https://parkerhiggins.net/2011/01/dice-mosaics/mickey-scaled/)
[![](https://parkerhiggins.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/recycle-scaled-150x150.png)](https://parkerhiggins.net/2011/01/dice-mosaics/recycle-scaled/)
[![](https://parkerhiggins.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/reversedpilcrow-scaled-150x150.png)](https://parkerhiggins.net/2011/01/dice-mosaics/reversedpilcrow-scaled/)
[![](https://parkerhiggins.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/star-scaled-150x150.png)](https://parkerhiggins.net/2011/01/dice-mosaics/star-scaled/)
[![](https://parkerhiggins.net/wp-content/uploads/2011/01/trebleclef-scaled-150x150.png)](https://parkerhiggins.net/2011/01/dice-mosaics/trebleclef-scaled/)

I’ll make a how-to in a future post, and after that I hope to document the actual construction of one or a few of these. Also, I relied heavily on, and am very thankful for, an excellent free software tool called Metapixel.
entry.summary: I put together some mosaics of common images using dice faces as tiles. So far they only exist in computerized form, but the hope is to buy some dice wholesale and actually arrange some of these on a board. I’m still experimenting with what kinds of source images make for good output, but for now I’ve stuck to simple black-and-white symbols and line drawings. I’d like to start using more grayscale and complex shapes, but the challenge is keeping the image clear at a resolution low enough that the dice are still discernible and reasonable to arrange. (Some of these contain thousands of dice, which is a bit impractical.)
